message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and has elevated glycated hemoglobin and blood glucose levels, indicating poor glucose control. Although the patient desires to avoid weight gain, insulin therapy may cause weight gain and is not the best initial treatment option for this patient. Exenatide and empagliflozin are also not the best initial treatment options for this patient due to the patient's desire to avoid weight gain and potential side effects of these medications. Metformin is a first-line agent for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus and is associated with weight loss, making it the best treatment option for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's HbA1c indicates uncontrolled diabetes and her glucose levels are still elevated despite her attempts to control with exercise and diet. Metformin is the first-line medication for type 2 diabetes mellitus and can improve glucose control without promoting weight gain. Insulin may cause weight gain and is usually reserved for more severe cases, while exenatide and empagliflozin may not be suitable for this patient's current situation.
